The main weakness of the course is that Prof. Fair, as smart as he is, is horribly boring and ineffective as a teacher. I am interested in economics and would have gone to every lecture if I thought I needed to. As the semester progressed, it became clear that the hour and a quarter block occupied by Econ 116 would be better used napping, eating, clocking work hours, studying for other classes, or just relaxing. Yale needs to do something about this problem.

The strengths of this course were the textbook, which explained most of the topics very well. This was necessary, because the subjects were not taught very well during lecture. It would also be useful to improve slides, so that it is easier to follow as a student, who has never engaged in macroeconomics before.

The problem sets were helpful in understanding the material. Section was often very clear and provided a great deal of help with the problem sets. The textbook was very digestable and well-written. However, lecture was a complete waste of time. It was disorganized and ver very dry. I often left lecture feeling less comfortable with the material than when I entered, so for the second half of the semester I didn't even go. And I was not alone. During exams it was amazing to see how many people actually took the class because once their name had been called to report your economic news one time, people just stopped coming, except to drop off their problem sets once a week.

The lectures could certainly be made to be more engaging. The slides also contained very little useful information, or if there was information, it was not clearly labelled and thus difficult to understand outside of the lecture setting. I think the class would benefit immensely from more explanatory and well-planned slides with pertinent information.  The PSets were helpful however, in reviewing and attempting to understand confusing material.
